title: 109_s1180
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Sheltering All Veterans Everywhere Act" or the "SAVE Reauthorization Act of 2005". Congress acknowledges the serious issue of homelessness in the United States, particularly among veterans. The Department of Veterans Affairs estimates that over 250,000 veterans are homeless on any given night. Homeless veterans have served in various wars and conflicts, with male veterans being twice as likely and female veterans almost four times as likely to become homeless compared to non-veteran counterparts. The United States Government must provide homeless or at-risk veterans with necessary services to prevent and end their homelessness. The programs reauthorized by this Act offer crucial housing and services for homeless veterans and should be reauthorized. SEC. 3. COMPREHENSIVE SERVICE PROGRAMS. Amends payment structure for grant and per diem grantees. Authorizes $200,000,000 for Homeless Providers Grant and Per Diem Program for fiscal years 2006 through 2011. 

SEC. 4. HOMELESS VETERANS REINTEGRATION PROGRAMS. SEC. 4. HOMELESS VETERANS REINTEGRATION PROGRAMS. Amends Section 2021(a) of title 38 to include veterans at imminent risk of homelessness. Authorizes $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2011. Section 2022 of title 38, United States Code is amended to include particular veterans and members of the armed forces separating from active duty. Plans are added to provide information on homelessness, including risk factors and preventative assistance. The amendment to Section 2022 of title 38, United States Code includes provision of information on homelessness, risk factors, awareness assessment, and contact information for preventative assistance associated with homelessness. SEC. 6. Treatment and rehabilitation for seriously mentally ill and homeless veterans extended to 2011. SEC. 7. Secretary of Veterans Affairs granted permanent authority to transfer properties obtained through foreclosure of VA home mortgages. SEC. 8. Grant program for homeless veterans with special needs extended to fiscal years 2005 through 2011. SEC. 9. Eligibility for dental care expanded. SEC. 9 expands eligibility for dental care by amending Section 2062(b) of title 38, United States Code. It removes the requirement for a 60-day consecutive period and eliminates paragraph (3). SEC. 11. ANNUAL REPORT ON ASSISTANCE TO HOMELESS VETERANS. Amends Section 2065(b) of title 38, US Code to include information on coordinating housing and services for homeless veterans with other federal departments and agencies. SEC. 12. ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HOMELESS VETERANS. SEC. 12. ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HOMELESS VETERANS. Amends Section 2066 of title 38, US Code to include the Executive Director of the Interagency Council on Homelessness in the advisory committee. Changes the deadline in subsection (d) from December 31, 2006, to September 30, 2011. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report by September 30, 2007, on the correlation between military sexual trauma and homelessness among veterans, along with effective service models for addressing trauma among homeless veterans to specific committees in Congress. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will allocate funds for a study on treatment modalities for homeless veterans with military sexual trauma, including an evaluation of the "Seeking Safety" treatment for homeless female veterans.
